metadata.title: Predictive value of sudden olfactory loss in the diagnosis of COVID-19 Authors: Corresponding Author

body_text.text: Viral upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) are one of the most common causes of olfactory loss. 2 Together with rhinoviruses, adeno-, influenza-, and parainfluenza viruses, coronaviruses have long 3 been known to account for at least 70% of common colds [1] . Compared to other respiratory 4 viruses however, the frequency of reported olfactory disorders in coronavirus infections was lower 5 so far and has never been a serious health issue [2,3,4]. 6 During an acute URTI, nasal congestion and rhinorrhea are commonly accompanied by a temporary 7 smell loss of varying severity. Significant olfactory loss without rhinitic symptoms however, is 8 comparatively rare and points towards damage of the olfactory epithelium. URTI-associated smell 9 loss typically occurs after the fifth decade of life and becomes apparent to the patients several days studies, a different pattern is seen in patients with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 1 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. Smell and/or taste loss have been observed in 5-80% of these patients 1 3

[6,7], sometimes as the only apparent symptom, at a younger age, and a very early stage of the 1 4 disease. The diagnostic accuracy of this symptom is controversially discussed considering the fact 1 5 that more than 200 viruses are known to cause URTIs with a subsequent olfactory loss.

The aim of this study was to investigate the frequency of olfactory loss in an out-patient population 1 7 who presented to a coronavirus testing center during a 2-week period and to evaluate the diagnostic 1 8 value of this symptom for screening procedures. Out of these patients, 32% were subsequently tested 2 positive for SARS-CoV-2. On the other hand, 2.8% of the patients without olfactory loss were 3 tested positive.

In this out-patient sample, 64.7% of COVID-19 patients observed smell and/or taste loss early or 5 even before other symptoms started. Compared to COVID-19 patients without smell loss they were 6 significantly younger and less severely affected. In contrast to other acute viral smell impairment, 7 COVID-19 associated smell loss seems to be only rarely accompanied by a severely blocked nose 8 and thus the effect on olfaction may be independent of nasal congestion.
